title: American_Top_40_1983_October_8th
description:
"We're counting down the most popular songs in the land and the hits don't stop till we get to the top."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this broadcast:

Casey says this is the first time in chart history that the number one and number two songs were written and produced by a single individual.

There is a former top five song in the countdown inspired by a sleeping lady's-room attendant.

Casey says that a track on the British release version of the Beatles album, "Sergeant Pepper's" can't be played on the radio because it would be against FCC broadcast regulations and then gives the details.

In the history of the album chart, only three bands have had a number one album after breaking up and then getting back together. One of them is in this countdown.

A man writes in asking for a long-distance dedication, but forgets to choose a song, so the AT40 staff picks a song for him.

Two listeners ask the question; "Have different songs with the same title ever been in the top 40 at the same time?" Casey says it has only happened twice (with songs named Crazy Love and Superstar), and plays portions of each of the songs.

There is a band in the top ten who was offered a record deal without recording any demos or performing any auditions. Casey explains.

LW#1: Total Eclipse Of The Heart - Bonnie Tyler
40:    Foolin' - Def Leppard
39:    Can't Shake Loose - Agnetha Faltskog
